HTML5 standard: Work began in 2003  Working Draft as of 2011[3]
HTML web browser features: N/A
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Work began in 1996[4]  Version 1 released in 1997

HTML web browser features: AmigaOS, MorphOS, Apple macOS, Linux, Microsoft Windows
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Apple macOS,  Linux, Microsoft Windows

HTML web browser features:
Android 2.3 and newer[5]
Apple iOS 6 and newer[5]
Symbian Belle[5]
BlackBerry OS 7 and 10[5]
Windows Phone 7 and newer[5]
Adobe Flash/AIR features:
Android 2.1 to 4.1[6][7]
Apple iOS (Adobe AIR only)[8]
BlackBerry 10 (up to OS 10.3.0)[9]
BlackBerry Tablet OS[10]
Windows RT

HTML web browser features:
PlayStation (PS4, PS3 and PS Vita)[11][12][13]
Nintendo Switch and Wii U[14][15][11][16]
Nintendo 3DS family (partial)[11]
Xbox One and Xbox 360[11][17]
Adobe Flash/AIR features:
PlayStation 3 (Flash 9.1) and PSP (Flash 6)
Wii (Flash Lite 3.1, equivalent to Flash 8)
Leapster (Flash 5 for games)
Dreamcast (Flash 4)

HTML web browser features: Full, permission-based access to web camera, microphone, accelerometer and GPS
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Full, permission-based access to web camera, microphone, accelerometer and GPS

HTML web browser features: 82.3% of websites (as of March 28, 2020)[18]
Adobe Flash/AIR features: 4.5% of websites (as of April 19, 2018)[19]

HTML web browser features: 97.5% of browser installations (as of February 2020)[20]
Adobe Flash/AIR features: 29% of browser installations (as of July 2019)[21]

HTML web browser features: Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) supported on ~97% of browsers[22]
Adobe Flash/AIR features: SWF with embedded graphics and AS3SVGRenderer

HTML web browser features: 90+%[23] support of Filters in CSS3 (e.g. Glow, Blur, Drop Shadow, Sepia)[24]
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Yes, applied to text or graphics (e.g. Glow, Drop Shadow, Bevel)[25]

HTML web browser features: Yes
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Yes, with Saffron Type System

HTML web browser features: Installed fonts and custom fonts using CSS 3 web fonts
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Installed fonts and embedded fonts[26]

HTML web browser features: Yes, implemented in most browsers, for system and custom fonts
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Yes, in most cases^2

HTML web browser features: Only supported inside "pre" tags
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Yes, with Text Layout Framework

HTML web browser features: Yes, via "div" tag and CSS styling
Adobe Flash/AIR features: No, but text fields can be resized in ActionScript

HTML web browser features: Yes, via "table" tag
Adobe Flash/AIR features: No, but text fields can be arranged into a grid

HTML5 standard: As of 2016[update], two specifications compete: CSS Regions[27] and CSS Overflow[28]
HTML web browser features: With CSS Regions, supported by Safari, IE11 and Edge[29]
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Yes, with Text Layout Framework[30]

HTML web browser features: JavaScript
Adobe Flash/AIR features: ActionScript, Pixel Bender

HTML5 standard: Cross-compiling C++ code to JavaScript via Emscripten
HTML web browser features: Native code execution with Google Native Client in Google Chrome, also supported with WebAssembly (experimental)
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Cross-compiling C++ code to run in Flash Player via FlasCC[31] AIR has AIR Native Extensions that allow loading native code, such as compiled C++ code.

HTML web browser features: Plaintext JavaScript with limited obfuscation, WebAssembly bytecode (experimental), GLSL for GPUs, in Canvas elements
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Compiled bytecode, can be obfuscated

HTML web browser features: CSS 3, HTML, XML, JSON[32]
Adobe Flash/AIR features: JSON, XML, Subset of CSS 1[33]

HTML web browser features: GZIP compression for HTML, JS and CSS files[34]
Adobe Flash/AIR features: LZMA or DEFLATE for SWF files

HTML web browser features: PNG, JPEG, SVG, Animated GIF[note 1][35]
Adobe Flash/AIR features: PNG, JPEG, JPEG-XR, Single-frame GIF[36][37]

HTML web browser features: 90+% support of H.264;[38] varying support of WebM and Ogg Theora (see HTML5 video)
Adobe Flash/AIR features: H.264, Sorenson Spark, and On2 VP6[39]

HTML web browser features: Supported by IE, Edge, Firefox, Chrome, Safari and Opera.[41]
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Flash Video, H.264 and partial support for MP4

HTML web browser features: ~94% support of MP3,[42] AAC[43] and WAV PCM; varying support of Ogg Vorbis, and WebM Vorbis (see HTML5 audio)
Adobe Flash/AIR features: MP3, WAV and AAC audio files or embedded sound

HTML web browser features: Supported on all major desktop browsers, with warning displayed.[45] Not yet widely supported on mobile
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Yes, with warning displayed

HTML web browser features: ~65% support of audio/video files.[46] All other files being plaintext, except for obfuscation
Adobe Flash/AIR features: No, binary formatted files can be decompiled, which is obfuscation

HTML web browser features: ~87% support of single file upload, and drag and drop of files onto browser[47]
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Support for single file upload and generation,[48]  AIR only: full create/read/write access to file system[49]

HTML web browser features: ~95% support for canvas element[50]
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Yes, via BitmapData class[51]

HTML web browser features: Yes, via JavaScript Typed Arrays[52]
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Yes, via ByteArray class[53]

HTML web browser features: Via Web Sockets to stream binary or XML data
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Yes, embedded or streaming binary data[54]

HTML web browser features: Yes, via Web storage, HTTP cookie, or Indexed DB to store binary, XML or JSON data[55]
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Yes, via Local Shared Objects to store AMF-formatted data

HTML web browser features: Can be included in meta tags
Adobe Flash/AIR features: Extensible Metadata Platform
